section.title: Readme First
section.item:
Mistakes can trip up Perforce. Some of them are due to flaws in Perforce's user interface, others are due to cvs habits.
Never create a directory before syncing -- If a directory exists in Perforce, always sync a file instead of using mkdir. In Windows, file names are case-insensitive. If you create a directory with the wrong case, Perforce will happily sync files into that directory. If you add a file, Perforce will create a new directory with the wrong capitalization.
Do not use the same directory for two clients -- Perforce does not know what is on your disk. It maintains a database of the files that it sent to you. If you use the same directory for two clients, this database will be wrong.
Define your first client -- Please create a client when you first run p4win. Perforce will complain that you don't have a default client set up the first time you run p4win. If you do not set up a new client, the command line will not work correctly.
Select "New client" from the client menu. Call it "userid-nt-all". Click 'Update'. Right click your client and select "Switch to". You can delete it later.
Do not override write protect -- If your editor reports a write protect error, do not override it. Use ' p4 edit' instead. Perforce sets write protect when it sync's a new revision. If you override it, Perforce does not know that you've modified the file.
For example, when you sync, Perforce updates every new revision in your clientspec. You may be editing one of these files. If you override write protect, you will wipe out the other person's changes.
Do not 'p4 edit' directories -- With CVS, you could edit any file and the checkin figured out what you modified. If you try to duplicate this with 'p4 edit ...', Perforce will submit all of your files. Better to use 'p4 edit' on the files you want to edit. If you use 'p4 revert -a' and forget the '-a', all of your edits will disappear!
In Emacs, use p4.el and '^X^Q'. In Visual C++ and other Windows editors, use .
Save all before sync -- Save all files before you sync with the depot. If you don't, Perforce will update the copy on disk, but your editor will have an old revision. To help avoid problems, use an integrated client (e.g., p4.el for emacs, or scc.dll for Visual C++).
Close edits before resolve -- If you need to resolve a file, close other copies first. Otherwise, the save of the merged file will fail, and the unmerged revision is submitted.
Be careful of p4 revert -- Perforce's revert command overwrites any changes that you made to a file. If you say p4 revert ..., all modified files will be overwritten. See the command documentation for
p4 revert.
Yours vs. Theirs ==> Destination vs. Source -- In p4 resolve, yours is not your file. Instead it is the destination for the resolve. This is confusing. Please have someone work with you for your first attempts at integrate and resolves.
Save your password -- In the Windows GUI password box, select "Save your password". Otherwise, the command line and SCC.DLL interfaces will not work.
Don't move your workspace -- Without letting Perforce know. The results could be disastrous! See Moving your workspace.
Do not use //product/... -- Do not use //product/... in clientspecs or branchspecs. It blocks Perforce for all users. See Why is Perforce slow?.
Avoid option 'nocrlf' -- If you use 'shared', you can edit files with Unix, Windows, or Mac conventions and Perforce will translate them to Unix conventions. If you use 'local' or 'crlf', you can edit text files with the same convention as your workstation (i.e., Windows on a Windows box).
If you use 'nocrlf', Perforce will ignore CR characters in text files. If you are not careful, CR characters can be checked into Perforce. See CRLF vs. LF.
Use quotes around '*' and '#' -- Perforce uses '*' as a wildcard and '#' as a revision marker. Command shells may expand the '*' and treat '#' as a comment. See Perforce's Tech Note 41.

li.p: Identify a label that contains the file ('p4 labels'). For example, 'copper-2169' is build 2169 of 'copper'. Then use Perforce's file command. For example, to list the files for apipackages.txt:
Be sure to include the leading '//', otherwise Perforce will only search for files in both your client and the label. It will report "No files found" if your client does not include the file.
Create a client that checks out the codeline. Then use 'p4 files ...myfile...' to locate your file. If you hit "MaxScanResults" then search each subdirectory.
Create a client that checks out all of the files that concern you.
Then use 'grep' or an editor with multi-file search. I use Visual C++ and TextPad. Both editors contain good multi-file search tools.

item.title: How to set your password
item.blockquote:
On Windows, set it from p4win: ' user::set password...'. It is stored encrypted. Use 'p4 set P4PASSWD' to determine its value.
To change your password, use the same menu item, ' user::set password...'.

On Unix, use p4 passwd to change your password.
After you have a password, use the /usr/local/bin/p4passwd.pl command on atlas:
atlas> /usr/local/bin/p4passwd.pl Enter your password: Created /users/rjohnson/.p4passwd atlas> This command creates a .p4passwd file in your home directory that is set to read only for the owner. Your password is stored in MD5 digest format within the file. This file needs to be referenced by your login files, for example:
In .cshrc,
if (-o .p4passwd) then chmod 600 .p4passwd setenv P4PASSWD `cat .p4passwd` endif

section.title: How To

item.title: How to add files and directories
item.p: To add directories to a Perforce depot, add one or more files from the directory. Perforce does not keep track of directories by themselves.
Use the 'p4 add' command to add files to a Perforce depot. You may do this on the command line or drag-and-drop with P4win.
With P4win, select the files or directories in Windows Explorer and drag them to a pending changelist (e.g., "default"). See the Help menu for more information
With the command line:

ul.li:
For UNIX or cygwin:
cd /home/user/p4work/clientdir
find . -type f -print | p4 -x - add

For Windows:
cd d:\p4work\clientdir
dir /s /b /a-d | p4 -x - add

item.p: With all methods, Perforce ignores files that already exist in the depot.
To create empty directories

ol.li: Check that your client uses option "normdir".
Add a dummy file for each directory (e.g., "temp.tmp")
Sync the dummy files. This will create the directories if they do not exist.

Sync the dummy files to none
p4 sync ...temp.tmp#none

item.title: How to add projects to a depot

section.item:
Adding a project to a depot is the same as
How to add files and directories
Your client must map the depot. The project directory must include a codeline (e.g., 'main/'). You need to add at least one file.
For example, to create "MyProj" in "//express":
Create a clientspec that maps //express. It should include a viewspec
//express/... //<clientname>/express...
Create subdirectories for MyProj/main
cd express
mkdir MyProj
cd MyProj
mkdir main
cd main
Create a file in main
echo "OK" >Readme.txt
Double-check the spelling, and add the file to Perforce.
p4 where Readme.txt
p4 add Readme.txt
p4 submit
If Perforce reports a write protect error,
Check that your file maps to //express/MyProj/main/Readme.txt.
Check that you have write permission to //express.
The depot name must already exist.
The third directory must be either "main" or another codeline.

item.title: How to avoid problems with cygwin

p.i: I use zsh and bash under Windows NT. Somehow, cygwin is mapping my P4ROOT to UNIX style, and thereby screwing up the string matching in P4. This means I can't use p4 with cygwin. [wsargent 3/01]

item.p: P4 works fine with Cygwin if you add an alias. This is from Cygwin and tcsh and cshrc.txt (use single quotes not double quotes)

item.title: How to cancel a submit
item.p: Cancelling a submit is easy to do in the P4 GUI: just hit the 'cancel' button.
In Unix,

ul.li: Cancel with a ^C before the edit window appears.
Cancel by quiting the editor without saving the submit form. Perforce will report that the "Description" is missing. Use ^C to exit.
Cancel by not changing "". Perforce will report that the "Description" is missing. Use ^C to exit.
In P4 for Emacs, cancel by exiting without using ^C^C to close the submit window.

item.title: How to control write access
item.p: To control write access to a codeline:

ol.li:
Ask Road to set up a protection group for the codeline. For example, 'escoe-version' controls write access to '//escoe/*/version/...'. The group is defined by a file and a section of p4_protect.txt
# //escoe - controlled access to version codelines open user * * -//escoe/*/version/... write group escoe-version * //escoe/*/version/... ... write user jwang * //road/Perforce/main/protections/group/escoe-version.txt
Edit the group file (e.g., escoe-version.txt) to add or subtract users.

item.p: To allow write access at the file level.

ol.li: Open the files for edit and lock them.
Unlocking a file opens up write access to your group.
Please avoid widespread use since open files effect everyone's performance.
Ask Road if you need to break someone else's lock.

item.title: How to create a new project
item.p: Create a new project by adding one or more files. You need to specify a codeline (e.g., "main") and a depot (e.g., //express).
To create a new project:

ol.li:
Goto the depot directory using the Explorer or command line
cd \p4\express

Create a directory for the project using NewFolder or the command line
mkdir plantronics
cd plantronics

Create a directory for the codeline using NewFolder or the command line. This is normally "main"
mkdir main
cd main

Create a file using an editor or command line.
touch Readme.txt

Add the file using the Perforce GUI or command line
p4 add Readme.txt

Submit the change
p4 submit

item.title: How to create an 'all' client
item.p: The 'all' client gives you access to every file in Perforce. You can use it the same as clients for specific codelines. It takes longer the refresh the directory listing, and operations need to be relative to a directory (e.g., 'p4 sync ...').
To create an 'all' client in p4win:

ol.li: Select ClientSpec > New...
Enter the clientname (e.g., bbarber-kane-all).
Enter the root directory (e.g., d:\p4work\all).
Click Update

item.p: To create an 'all' client with p4:

ol.li:
Create a new root directory and a p4config.txt file
cd d:\p4work
mkdir all
cd all
echo "P4CLIENT=bbarber-kane-all" >p4config.txt

Create the client and exit
p4 client

item.title: How to ignore whitespace
item.p: To always ignore whitespace when diffing a file

ul.li: Goto Settings>Options>Diff/Merge
Select "Ignore diffs" under "Diff Application/Whitespace".
Alernatively, plug in another diff/merge program. See "Merge and Diff utilities" in Road's Software URL's

item.title: How to install Araxis Merge
item.p: Also download an evaluation copy of Araxis Merge from www.araxis.com.

Run the installer. After you start Perforce, use Settings::Options::Diff/Merge to use Araxis Merge instead of the built-in diff/merge tool. Use Araxis' compare.exe for the Diff Application and merge.exe for the Merge Application.
Consider buying Guiffy Merge, a Java-merge tools with intra-line diffs.

item.title: How to map the //user/*/ depot directory to http://intranet.

section.item:
Files placed in
//user//main/web/... are automatically published at
http://intranet/p4/user//...
See the Depot doc for more information.

item.title: How to map two depot directories to one client directory
item.p: Use the undocumented "+" mapping to map multiple depot directories to one client directory. Be careful, Perforce will blindly try to sync the same file or directory from each depot. Use 'p4 where' to find the files location in the depot.
From 'p4 help undoc'
item.pre: + mappings A mapping line that begins with + does not mask lower precedent mappings so that, for example, it is possible to map multiple server directories to the same client directory in the client view. The support for this is only partial, in that if two server files end up mapping to the same client file, the 'p4 sync' command will repeatedly replace one file with another.
item.p: There is no easy way to map one depot directory to multiple client directories. Tony Smith of Perforce offers the following suggestion:
item.blockquote: Branch the files to their multiple locations and have a script to keep the slave branches in sync with the master - and use protections to restrict updates to the subordinate copies.

item.title: How to move your local workspace
item.p: It's important to remember that Perforce tracks each client's state completely on the server.

This means that whenever you make any significant changes to your local disk or to where your client's root is on your local disk you MUST make the Perforce server aware of the change in circumstances or else undesirable events may ensue.
So, first, before touching your client, let's "put your house in order" before the move.

ul.li: For safety's sake, back up any important data in your workspace, or better yet, back your entire workspace up! If you need help with this contact IT and let them know you're trying to back up an important work/data directory.

See if you have any opened (marked for edit) files on this client using: p4 opened. If you do, save a copy of any changes and then p4 revert the file OR alternately if you're absolutely sure it's what you want do a p4 submit and commit the changes.

When you're sure your current workspace is OK / ready to be scrapped, do a p4 sync #none and Perforce will delete all the (now vestigial :) files on your client. This is what we want as Perforce will be ready for the move.

item.p: That's it for prep work, now the move itself is trivial:

ul.li: Make a fresh directory for your new client's root. If there's already files in the location you intend to use, move the old directory away and create a fresh new one. This will save you headache down the road.
Actually change your client's Root: line to the new location.
Now just p4 sync to refresh your workspace's files in its/their new location.
That's it! You should be all set. If you have any difficulties please drop an E-mail to the Road Team or give us a call.

item.title: How to place your home directory under P4
item.p: Will Sargent recommends placing your home directory under Perforce. You can keep your scripts and working documents under source control and synchronize all of your workstations (including NT if you use Cygwin).

ol.li:
For each workstation [substitute your userid and host]
cd ~/ echo "P4CLIENT=userid-host-home" >p4config.txt p4 client

Edit the clientspec to read [substitute your userid and host]
Root: /users/userid View: //user/userid/main/home/... //userid-host-home/...
Instead of using .../main/home/... for your home directory, you can use .../main/... and use //user/userid/dev/... for other directories (e.g., a private branch of a project).
Use p4 add xyz to add files in your home directory to Perforce.
Use p4 synch to sychronize home directories on different machines

item.title: How to remove files from your client workspace
item.p: To remove files from your client workspace

ul.li:
From the GUI
Right-click on a file or directory.
Select 'Remove from client'.
The GUI will display "#0/n" for the corresponding files.

From the command line
p4 sync xyz.txt#none
Other choices are #0 and @0.

item.title: How to rename a clientspec
item.p: [georgeo]: How do you rename a client? Create a new one and delete the old one??
Yes. The easiest way to create the new client is to use the command line and edit the Client: field. It will create a new client.
Alternatively, create a new client by right-clicking on the old client and selecting using "Create/Update client ... as template"
Delete the old client when you are done.

item.title: How to rename directories or files
item.p: To rename one or more files, you need to integrate the files to their new location, and delete them from the old. The old files must be in your workspace. The new files must be in your clientview.
Note: Always make the delete and integ part of the same changelist. Otherwise another integ using the same mapping will delete the destination files (since the delete wasn't propagated earlier).
Related links:

ul.li: How to reorganize a codeline or Java package
How to rename with a branch spec

item.p: With the Windows GUI,

ol.li: Select the directory or file you want to rename
Right click and select "Sync.." to retrieve the lastest revisions.
Right click and select "Integrate...".
Select "using filespec..."
Enter the new location.

Click Options.
Select "Delete old files for rename."
If there are many files, select "Do not copy new files". This avoids copying the files to their new location.
Click OK. Review the log messages for errors or check your changelist. The later should have equal numbers of delete and integrate operations.
Right click the changelist and select Submit.

item.p: Use a similar sequence of commands on the command line.

ol.li: Use 'p4 sync _old_' to get the old revisions.
Use 'p4 integrate _old_ _new_' to move the files to their new location. If there are many files, include option '-v' to avoid copying the new files.
Use 'p4 delete _old_' to delete the old files
Use 'p4 submit' to copy them over.

item.title: How to rename with a branch spec
item.p: Use a branchspec to rename several directories at once. For example.

ol.li:
Integrate to move the files from one place to another. Use option '-v' to avoid copying new files into your workspace. Pipe the results through 'tail' for faster output on large integrates. It shows the last log messages.
p4 integrate -b bbarber-fix-rev51_locale_head

Retrieve the old files. They need to be in your workspace for the delete. Note the use of "*" to prevent filename completion
p4 delete "//product/*/rev51_locale_head/..."

Delete the old files. Note: Always make the delete and integ part of the same changelist. Otherwise another integ using the same branch mapping will delete the destination files (since the delete wasn't propagated earlier).
p4 delete "//product/*/rev51_locale_head/..."

Check that the number of branched files is the same as the number of deleted files
p4 opened | grep " delete " | wc p4 opened | grep " branch " | wc

Submit your change
p4 submit

ul.li: How to rename directories or files
How to reorganize a codeline or Java package

item.title: How to reorganize a codeline
item.p: Perforce does not offer a move command similar to moving the CVS repository files. With care, you can edit a checkpoint file. See the P4 Admin FAQ.
For simple reorgs:

ol.li:
Rename the files using integ and delete
p4 integ //dev/epub/main/... //product/Publishing/main/...
p4 delete //dev/epub/main/...
p4 submit

Add the mapping to the end of any active branches
//dev/epub/version/6.0.0/... //product/Publishing/main/...

Identify the changelist for the branch
p4 changes //dev/epub/version/6.0.0/... | tail

Sync the branch as of the changelist and ignore the branch. 'p4 integrated' will record the new location of the branched files.
p4 opened # no open files
p4 integ -i -b 0_rev_600_to_main //product/Publishing/main/...@259060
p4 integ -i -b 0_rev_600_to_main //product/EcoVida/main/...@259060 | tail
p4 resolve -ay | tail
p4 change
p4 submit -c 264814 | wc

item.title: How to reorganize a codeline or package
item.p: When you reorganize a codeline or package, you are creating a new file and deleting the old file. Parallel codelines may be changing the same file. Use the following procedure to minimize merge conflicts.
If you change a top-level name, please review all clients that may use the old name (e.g., 0-main-eisbock for P4 Change Reports).
To reorganize the mainline:

ol.li: Synchronize parallel development branches with the mainline [ How to merge and synchronize].

Use a filespec or branchspec to reorganize the mainline
How to rename directories or files
How to rename with a branch spec.
Synchronize parallel development branches with the mainline.

item.p: Reorganizing a branch takes more care. You need to update the synchronization branch spec.

ol.li: Synchronize the branch with the mainline [ How to merge and synchronize].
Create a branchspec for the reorganization [ How to rename with a branch spec].
Use the branchspec to reorganize the codeline.

In the branchspec, replace the source codeline (e.g., 'dev/copper/') with the mainline (i.e., 'main/'). Append the branchspec to the synchronization branchspec. It should map from the old location in the mainline to the new location on the branch.

[This step doesn't work well. It needs an enhancement to p4d.] Synchronize the branch with the mainline using a baseless merge [ How to merge between branches (baseless)]. All of the reorganized files will be in the changeset. This updates Perforce's integration database.

item.p: To generate a merge report from a reorganized codeline, collect the list of files using the old branchspec, and then integrate these files into the new branchspec. Be sure that you have write access into the old branchspec. Generate future merge reports starting at the changelist number of the reorg. See Merge Report for detailed instructions.
See also How to reorganize a depot

item.title: How to restore deleted files
item.p: Perforce stores all revisions of a file. When you delete a file with 'p4 delete', it does not actually delete the file.

If you restore a deleted file, do not change the file at the same time. Perforce will not propagate the change correctly [see below for examples]. To be sure that your re-added file is propagated correctly, consider propagating your change to active code branches [see below for instructions]
To restore a deleted file with p4win [hmai]:

ol.li: View all deleted files by selecting "Show deleted depot files" on the Edit menu.
Select the file you want to restore.
Right-click and select "Revision history ...".
Select the revision you want to restore.
Click the "sync" (or right-click and sync).
Close the Revision history menu
Right-click and select "Recover deleted file".
Double check that the file is correct.
Submit your change.

item.p: To restore a deleted file with the command line [Perforce Note 008]

ol.li: sync to the last good revision of the file.
add the file.

item.p: For example, if foo.c was deleted at revision 26,
item.pre: p4 sync foo.c#25 p4 add foo.c p4 submit
item.p: Or worse, if change 300 deleted all of the files in the current directory:
item.pre: p4 sync ...@299 p4 add ... p4 submit
item.p: Always restore the file, before making a modification. Otherwise sync merges will fail to propagate your change. For example:
item.pre:
Good sequence: - file#1: created a new file Branched the file file#2: modified the file file#3: modified the file Sync merge with the branch file#4: delete the file file#5: restore file#3 file#6: modify the file, either a new modification or as an earlier revision such as file#2 Sync merge with the branchn - branch is #6, as expected
Bad sequence: file#1: created a new file Branched the file file#2: modified the file file#3: modified the file Sync merge with the branch file#4: deleted the file file#5: recreate the file and at the same time, modify some lines Sync merge with the branch - branch is #3 instead of #5
Another bad sequence - file#1 - created a new file file#2 - modified the file file#3 - modified the file Sync merge with the branch file#4 - deleted the file file#5 - restored file#2 Sync merge with the branch - branch is #3 instead of #5
item.p: Even if you restore the previous version, sync merges may fail. Perforce treats a re-added file exactly like a newly added file. It ignores any previous change history. For example,
item.pre: Another bad sequence - file#1 - created a new file file#2 - modified the file Branch the file file#3 - modified the file file#4 - deleted the file file#5 - restored file#3 Sync merge with the branch - branch is #2 instead of #5
item.p: In all cases, Perforce will require the '-i' flag before it will perform the integrate. Here's the explanation as best I understand it. Perforce requires the -i flag in several different situations. To Perforce, all of these situations look the same.

ol.li:
If you are merging between two related branches (e.g., version/6.1.0 and version/6.2.0) and there are no delete and re-adds.
This is called a "baseless merge". You need to use 'integ -i'. This appears to work well, though it includes files that haven't changed. If you use indirect merge (integ -I) [cap-i] Perforce will skip unchanged files. Baseless merges work well for change propagation.

If two files, by accident, have the same name on the main line and a branch.
If neither file has changed, Perforce keeps the destination file. While this case is rare, it should be considered whenever Perforce requires the '-i' flag. One of the files should be renamed.

If the same file is added to both the main line and a branch.
All is OK, since the files are the same.

If a file is deleted, re-added, but not further modified.
Any modifications since the last sync merge will be ignored.

If a file is deleted, re-added, and then modified
The merge may be garbled.

item.p: If you perform a sync merge and Perforce requires '-i',

ol.li: Do not use automatic resolve or safe automatic resolve.
Review the revision history for both files (p4 filelog).

If there was a delete and re-add,
Try a 'p4 resolve'. If the default action is '-at (Copy Into)', it is the correct action.
If not, verify that the branch either has a copy of the restored file, or has not branched the file.
If the re-added file was modified at the same time, but the branch was not modified, 'accept theirs (Copy Into)'.
If the re-added file was modified at the same time, and the branch was modified, sync merge up to the delete, sync merge the remainder, then merge the modification by hand.
If both branch and mainline changed multiple times, sync merge up to the restored revision, then sync merge the remainder.
See " How to synchronize branches".

item.title: How to restore old revisions
item.p: To restore an old revision of a file or files

ol.li: sync to the old revision
edit these files. Perforce will report that a resolve is needed.
sync to the head revision.
resolve -ay to accept your old revisions and ignore the depot's head revision. Note: double check that resolve -ay was not applied to other files.
submit the changes

item.p: A similar process is used to undo a change. See Perforce Note 014.

item.title: How to set the execute bit

ul.li:
To set the execute bit on a text file, xyz.sh
p4 edit -t kxtext xyz.sh
p4 submit

To set the execute bit on a binary file, gcc
p4 edit -t xbinary gcc
p4 submit

item.title: How to set your UNIX environment variables
item.p: Perforce needs to have several environment variables set to work properly. Here are samples for both csh style and sh style login dotfiles:
for .cshrc,
item.pre: setenv P4PORT perforce:1666 setenv P4CONFIG p4config.txt setenv P4USER $USER setenv P4CLIENT $USER-$HOST-all if (-o .p4passwd) then chmod 600 .p4passwd setenv P4PASSWD `cat .p4passwd` endif
item.p: for .profile,
item.pre: export P4PORT=perforce:1666 export P4CONFIG=p4config.txt export P4USER=$USER export P4CLIENT=$USER-$HOST-all if [ -f .p4passwd ]; then chmod 600 .p4passwd export P4PASSWD=`cat .p4passwd` fi

item.title: How to synchronize your workspace with Perforce
item.p: Suppose that you have created a client workspace on your laptop, and that you want to work detached from the network. Once you return to the network, you need some way to determine which of your local files have been added, deleted or modified. See also What files are not checked into Perforce?
To synchronize your workspace with Perforce:

ol.li:
p4 edit modified files
p4 diff -se | p4 -x - edit

p4 add new files
Unix: find . ! -type d | p4 -x - add
Windows: dir /s /b /a-d | p4 -x - add

p4 delete deleted files
p4 diff -sd | p4 -x - delete
Note: If you had deleted file that was opened for edit, you need to p4 revert the file first.

p4 revert -a unmodified and unopened files
p4 diff -sr | p4 -x - revert -a

p4 submit your changes. Review the list of submited files.
p4 submit

item.title: How to undo a change
item.p: Perforce Technote 014 describes how to undo changes.
Note: Use this procedure to undo adds, edits, and deletes. It does not work for integrates.
To immediately undo a changelist (for example @2000) or to replace a file with a previous revision:

ol.li: sync to the previous change ('sync @1999') or previous file revision ('sync myfile.txt#34').

edit these files. Perforce will report that a resolve is needed.
To undo a deleted file, use add instead of edit.
Do not use edit for newly added files (see below).
lock these files to prevent additional changes.
changes for these files. Make sure no one else has modified them.
sync to the head revision.

resolve -ay to accept your old revisions and ignore the depot's head revision. This is not needed for added files.
Note: Be careful of using 'resolve -ay'. It ignores the depot revision.
To undo a newly added file, delete the file.
submit the change

item.p: A similar process is used to recover an old revision.
To undo an old changelist (edits only) (for example @2000)

ol.li: sync to the previous changelist ('sync @1999')

edit these files. Perforce will report that a resolve is needed.
To undo a deleted file, use add instead.
Ignore files that were added by the old changelist.
sync to the old changelist ('sync @2000')
resolve -ay to ignore the old changelist
sync to the head revision.
resolve to merge the "undo" into the head revision
To undo an added file, delete the file.
submit the change

item.p: If you do not want to edit each file in step (2) explicitly, you can open every file for edit (p4 edit ...), sync and resolve, and then revert the unchanged files (p4 revert -a ...).

item.title: How to undo a rename
item.p: Perforce uses p4 integrate old new and p4 delete old to rename files and directories. If you try to reverse this process, Perforce reports that all changes in new are already in old. The problem is that old was deleted after the integrate.
To undo a rename from old to new at changelist 2000

ol.li: sync old the old files to the previous changelist ('sync @1999'). Your old files are restored.
add old the old files.
sync old to the head revision.
integrate new old to copy any changes made to the new files after the rename.
delete new the rename location.
Check the result.
submit the change

item.title: How to branch a codeline
item.p: Branch a codeline whenever you want to make independent changes. The branch makes a "lazy" copy of the codeline. Files are not actually copied until they are changed. Changes to the branch can be merged into the original codeline and vice versa.

Use a three-level naming convention for its codelines. The first two levels identify the depot and project while the third level identifies the codeline (e.g., //product/DAS/dev/STaglib10b1 is the "dev/STaglib10b1" branch of "DAS"). Besides branching codelines, you can branch any directory or file.

ol.li:
Select the "all" clientspec, or add the appropriate mapping to your client spec:
//express/Fox/dev/simpson/... //myclient/Fox-simpson/...
Verify that you have write access to all destination codelines.

integrate from the source to the destination of the branch.
p4 integrate -v -b mybranch
Check each codeline of your branch. Perforce silently ignores a codeline if you do not have write permission, or if the codeline is not in your clientspec.

submit the new codeline.
p4 submit

item.p: To branch a lot of files

ol.li: Create a clientspec for the codeline or use an "all" clientspec
Verify that you have write access to all destination codelines.

Make sure that you do not have other opened files.
p4 opened

Create a branch specification using a similar branchspec as a model.
p4 branch 0_rev_main_to_amber

integrate from the source to the destination of the branch. Avoid copying the physical files with option '-v' ('Do not copy files' in the GUI). Pipe the output for a faster response.
p4 integrate -v -b 0_rev_main_to_amber | wc

Create a changelist and document what you have done. Mention the branch spec in your changelist.
p4 change
Check each codeline of your branch. Perforce silently ignores a codeline if you do not have write permission, or if the codeline is not in your clientspec.

submit the new codeline. Pipe the output for a faster response.
p4 submit -c nnnnn | wc

item.p: See following for branching a version codeline.
See also Perforce Technote 004 on How do you branch a codeline?. It includes instructions on using the branch spec to merge changes.

item.title: How to branch and modify in one step
item.p: Note: Although you can branch and modify a file in one step [see following], it is better to branch the file and modify in separate steps. This keeps the integration record clean. For example, if you are renaming a Java package, use 'p4 integ', 'p4 delete', and 'p4 submit' to rename the package; then edit the files to modify the package names.

Sometimes you need to branch a file and modify it in one step. For example, you want to rename a Java package. This is a p4 integrate newname followed by a p4 delete oldname. Each of the Java files also need editing to change the package specifier. Jeff Bowles wrote the following:
Perforce supports a sometimes-mentioned mechanism for this, which "p4 help integrate" will tell you a bit about: you can run two commands back-to-back for this purpose:
item.pre: p4 integrate Comedy/Simpsons/... Classic/Simpsons/... p4 add Classic/Simpsons/...
item.p: Note that there's no intervening "p4 submit". This sequence downgrades the integrate to be a sorta "integrate+add" mechanism, so that the files that you're putting into the new place are marked writeable and you can change all the package statements prior to a "p4 submit". That way, the first revision in the new name contains contents that actually make sense.

And better than that, "p4 filelog -i" and "p4 changes -i" on the new codeline still work because it's preserved those integration records. A lone "p4 add" (not this downgraded integrate operation) wouldn't have done that.

If you do this from one branch/codeline to another, which is okay, be aware that when you try to push content BACK to the parent codeline later it'll try to push your modified "package" (or whatever) statements back, also. So the first reverse-integrate should be done with a bit of caution.
For Java hackers, this is an important little detail that comes up when you're pushing files around to make a new package or copying the source file for a class from one place to another.

item.title: How to ignore a change during a merge
item.p: Integrate the change. When you resolve the change, use "accept yours". The change history will report that you "ignored" the change.
Note: Do not use "accept theirs". It will throw out the current revision of the file, and replace it with your changed revision.
To undo an ignored change, use 'p4 integ -f'. It will perform the integration despite the previously existing integration record.

item.title: How to merge
item.p:
Note:
Try to find someone to teach you merging. It will help you avoid mistakes. Be careful of Perforce's use of "yours" and "theirs". It is confusing. Instead of "yours" and "theirs", think of "destination" and "source". Think of yourself standing on the destination files and pulling the change from the source. If you "accept theirs" you are accepting the change. If you "accept yours" you are ignoring the change.
Perforce keeps track of every change and every merge. For example, it can record that file X branched from the fourth revision of file Y and contains the seventh through tenth revision of file Y,

It is easiest to merge using the Windows GUI. You can either use a file specification for merging a directory, or a branch specification for merging multiple directories. For all merges, the procedure is

ol.li: sync the destination files (aka "target files").
integrate from the source to the destination. This copies new changes from the source to the destination. You can select specific changes.

resolve differences between source and destination. Use 'safe auto-resolve' to resolve files changed only in the source or destination. Use 'auto-resolve' to resolve non-conflicting changes. Use the GUI's interactive resolve to resolve the remaining changes.
submit the modified destination files.

item.p: To propagate an individual change, see How to propagate a change.
To merge with the Windows GUI

ol.li: Use a branchspec to merge multiple directories. Have someone set this up for you if needed. Then right-click on the branchspec and select "Integrate using ...".
To merge a single directory, right-click on the source directory and select "Integrate... using FileSpec..."
Select "sync target files first".
Specify the target FileSpec. It specifies the destination files for the merge.
In Options, select "Permit deletes/re-adds" to delete or add files.
In Options, select "Enable baseless merges" if merging between unrelated branches [see below for more information].
In Options/Source Revision Range, enter "Other: @NNN" to start or end with a specific changelist.
Select OK and review for error messages.
Go to the default change list, and look for unresolved icons.
Skip the following five steps ("Resolve/Auto-resolve") if you do not have many files to resolve.
Right click an unresolved merge and select 'Resolve/Auto-resolve'.
Select "Resolve all files"
Select "Safe autoresolve"
Select Preview and review the files for auto-resolve. Use 'Resolve/Interactively' if there are any questions. For example, you may have merged another persons changes by accident.
If everything looks good, select OK. Perforce will perform the one-way merges.
Right click an unresolved merge and select 'Resolve/Interactive'.
Select "Use interactive merge" [?]
Review each change. Conflicting changes are colored red. Right-click on the block you want, and select "use this block".
Close the merge window. Type 'Enter' to save your changes.
Select "Accept merged file" [?]
When all done, right-click the default change list, and select Submit.

item.p: Perforce doesn't keep track of how something was merged. For example, when you merge change 3544 from Y to X, you can tell Perforce to ignore the change for this file ("accept yours" in Perforce-speak). Perforce records that you merged @3544 from Y to X, but not that you ignored the change. [FIXUP: it does record some things]

Perforce performs 3-way merges. For example if you branch Y from X at X#34 and make three changes to Y and 10 changes to X, Y is at Y#4 and X is at X#44. If you merge Y back into X, The source (aka. "theirs") is Y#4, the base is X#34 (i.e., Y#1), and the destination (aka. "yours") is X#44. This will produce a new revision of X (X#45).

item.title: How to merge and synchronize branches (command line)
item.p: Many files may be involved when a merge is used to synchronize one branch with another (e.g., synchronize dev/copper with main). If so, the command line is easier and faster than the GUI

ol.li:
Select a client that directly maps the destination (e.g., an 'all' client). Do not use the devtools client; it is too complicated. Check that the destination client and branch spec map the same set of files.
p4 client -o
p4 branch -o 0_rev_main_to_copper
Optionally review the merge with a Merge Report of unintegrated changes from souce to destination.

If you are retiring the source branch, check if anyone has opened files. Ask these users to submit their changes.
p4 opened -a ... | sed -e 's/.* by //' -e 's/@.*//' | sort -u

Check that you do not have opened files. If you do, move them to a separate changelist or revert them.
p4 opened

Verify that you do not have opened files. If you have opened files, your changelist will consist of new and old files. A mess! [bbarber @262003]
p4 opened

Integrate source into destination. files. Include the '-t' option if file types should be propagated from source to destination.
p4 integ -b 0_rev_main_to_copper | wc

Check for errors, baseless merges, added files, and deleted files that were independently changed.
p4 integ -b 0_rev_main_to_copper | tee integ.txt
If the '-i' or '-d' flag is required for a sync merge, merge each file individually.
Review the file log for the source and destination file.
Notify the recent owners if you do not understand what is happening. Let them merge this file. Do not merge the file and ask the developer to review the change.
For example, newly added files need the '-i' option.
Be careful. For example, if a developer deleted and re-added a file, Perforce treats the newly added file, exactly like a new file. It ignores any previous change history. If the default resolve action is 'ignore from (-ay)', you may need to override the selection. See " How to restore deleted files".
For example, if you have reorganized the destination and updated the branch, the old source files need to be reintegrated with the '-i' option.
Be careful. For example, if a file was deleted prior to the branch and then recreated, 'p4 integ -d' will delete the file again.
For example, if every file was touched on the destination branch, then deletes will not be integrated.
See the command documentation for p4 integ. It is too brief, but better than nothing at all.

Automatically merge most files. Do not automatically merge '-i' and '-d' files (see previous step).
p4 resolve -am | wc

Automatically resolve binary files that either didn't change or changed on only one brach. Use safe automatic merge (-as) on the binary files (-t)
p4 resolve -t -as
The remaining binary files changed on both source and destination. You will need to resolve the conflicts by hand [see following].

What else needs to be resolved?
p4 resolve -n

Resolve conflicts or files that contain binary data. 'Skip' if you want someoneelse to resolve the conflicts.
p4 resolve

Are you merging back into the mainline from a branch? If so, edits due to old conflicts may still conflict on the mainline. List the files and check that all revisions on the mainline were merged into the branch.
If all changes on the mainline were integrated into the branch, you can safely move the files from the branch to the mainline [p4 resolve -at]

List the last changelist for the remaining conflicts. Each line of 'resolve -n' matches the same line of 'changes -m1'
p4 resolve -n
p4 resolve -n | sed 's/ - .*/#have/' | p4 -x - changes -m1

Review the differences. Revert any suspicious files and notify the developers.
p4 diff | tee diff.txt

Notify the developers. For example,
You have a conflict during the main to copper merge.
In a dev/copper directory, please run
p4 integ -b 0_rev_main_to_copper -s //main/2005/product/... p4 resolve. [Fix any problems] p4 submit
Thanks for your help.

Undo any skipped merges that you do not want to attempt now. You can retry later.
p4 resolve -n | tee resolve.txt | sed 's/ - .*//' | p4 -x - revert

Create a change list. Start the Description with "Sync ..."
p4 change

Submit your changes
p4 submit -c nnnn | wc
If you used '-d', review the deleted files. The only changes should be synchronizations and merges. See What files were mistakenly deleted?

item.title: How to merge between branches (baseless)
item.p: If Perforce does not find a common ancestor, you can force a "baseless" merge. It will use the first revision of the first file as the base.

A baseless merge occurs when the source was not branched from the destination (or vice versa). Even if both branches came from main, the later branch does not record that it already has rev #1 of the former.
Baseless merges are OK for small changes. For large branches, a baseless merge will touch every file. If the branch will be merged into main, then all concurrent branches will also be touched.

Note: If possible, please revert unchanged files before finishing the baseless merge. Otherwise, every file is touched. If you don't do this, then further sync's with the mainline, must use 'integ -d' to carry over deleted files due to a rename.
For further help with baseless merges see

ul.li: Technote 009 How to merge changes that are not branched.

item.p: If there are not many files:

ol.li: p4 integ -i -b 0_rev_after56_to_amber
p4 resolve
verify the result
p4 submit

item.p: If there are many files, the process is similar to syncing branches.

ol.li:
Check the source for clients with opened files. There should be no opened files if you are retiring the source branch.
p4 opened -a ... | sed -e 's/.* by //' -e 's/@.*//' | sort -u

Sync the destination files (aka "target files").
p4 sync | wc
Synchronize the target with the mainline. See How to merge and synchronize for instructions. This will prevent conflicts for later synchronizations.

Integrate source into destination. Use the '-i' flag for the baseless merge.
p4 integ -i -b 0_rev_main_to_bock | wc
p4 integ -i -b 0_rev_main_to_bock

If Perforce does not integrate deleted or added files, consider using option '-d'. For example, if every file was touched on the destination branch, then deletes will not be integrated. Be careful. For example, if a file was deleted prior to the branch and then recreated, 'p4 integ -d' will delete the file again. See the command documentation for p4 integ.

Automatically merge most files. This will take a while since Perforce will merge every file, even though the file did not change.
p4 resolve -am | wc

List the binary files. Binary files are not automatically merged.
p4 opened | grep 'binary)' | sed 's/#.*//'

To resolve binary files that either didn't change or changed on one brach, use safe automatic merge (-as) on the binary files (-t)
p4 resolve -t -as
The remaining binary files changed on both source and destination. You will need to resolve the conflict by hand.

What else needs to be resolved?
p4 resolve -n

Resolve conflicts or files that contain binary data
p4 resolve

Revert any skipped merges that you do not want to attempt now. You can retry later (it will go much faster).
p4 resolve -n | sed 's/ - .*//' | p4 -x - revert

Revert unmodified files. This should dramatically reduce the changeset. See the previous note. Please avoid repeated merges with unrelated branches.
p4 diff -sr | p4 -x - revert

Create a change list
p4 change

Submit your changes
p4 submit -c nnnn | wc

item.title: How to propagate a change
item.p: To propagate a change between branches and the mainline (Perforce GUI):

ol.li: Install 2002.1 - You need a 2002.1 client
Check that your client maps the destination branch and that you have write access. You may use an 'all' client that maps all depots.
Locate your change in the Changes window.
Right-click on the change and select "Integrate ... using branchspec".
Select the branchspec (e.g., 0_rev_main_to_600beta2).
Delete the list of source files [This is a UI bug].

Select "Preview" and check the Status window.
"no target file(s) in both client and branch view" - either your client does not map the destination or you do not have write permission. For the copper beta branch, you need to be in copper-beta.txt.
need write permission - You do not have write permission for the destination of the branch. [Note: If you selected "From Selected Files", Perforce incorrectly reports that the source lacks write permission.]
Select "Finish".
Locate your changelist in Pending ChangeLists.
Resolve the integrated files. See How to merge steps 9 and following.

item.p: To propagate a change between branches and the mainline (p4 command line):

ol.li: Check that your client maps the destination branch and that you have write access. You may use an 'all' client that maps all depots.
Sync the destination files. [This step is not needed after the upgrade to 2002.1]

Integrate the change by listing the change number twice.
p4 integ -b 0_rev_511_to_main @23456,@23456

If perforce reports "no target file(s) in both client and branch view", either your client does not map the destination or you do not have write permission.
For the Copper beta branch, check 'p4 groups userid'. Only 'copper-beta' users can check in code.

Resolve the merge
p4 resolve

Review the results
p4 diff

Submit the results
p4 submit

Check that there are no opened files
p4 opened

Integrate the changes for this directory
p4 integ -b 0_rev_600_to_main //version/Rev_6.00/...

Resolve and merge the files
p4 resolve

Review and submit your change
p4 submit

item.title: How to resolve a merge (details)
item.p: Perforce's 'resolve' command performs a 3-way merge. It identifies differences between the base version and the source and destination versions. For example, the following resolve reports 18 differences in the destination (aka "yours") and 1 difference in the source (aka "theirs").
item.blockquote: Diff chunks: 18 yours + 1 theirs + 0 both + 0 conflicting
item.p: The best way to see/list all the diff chunks is to view them in Perforce's interactive merge (p4WinMrg). This "guy" uses the same algorithm. The diff logic used (hard-coded) by Perforce is very close to the GNU Diff algorithm. [A. Markin]
See also

ul.li: How to merge (details) [Perforce]

item.p: We use a Perforce presubmit trigger, //road/Perforce/main/triggers/require-jobs.pl, to require BUGS-FIXED: for version codelines.
To identify which bugs do not have an associated fix

ol.li:
List the changes for a codeline
p4 changes ...@264821,#head | sed 's/^Change/bugnnnnnn fixed by change/' > changes.txt

List the fixes for a codeline

item.p: How do you list files that were modified in 6.0.0 patch 2 [sharemink]?

Alternatively, use
For a structured report, use the P4 Change Reports. For examples, see the "bug-changes" link for pre-computed change reports.

item.title: What changelist am I sync'd to?
item.p:
Use p4 changes -m1 #have
or
p4 changes -m1 # clientname

item.title: What changelist corresponds to a date?
item.p: Perforce does not provide a command to convert a date to the corresponding changelist number. You can determine the changelist by one of the following methods:

ul.li:
Search the list of recent changes
p4 changes -m 10000 | grep 2002/12/09:19

Select a focused client that maps the changes that interest you.
p4 changes -m 1 ...@2002/12/09:19:00:00

To avoid maxresults for large clients, add a lower-bound changelist number, say @263000
p4 changes -m 1 '...@>263000,@2002/12/09:19:00:00'
Use the date instead of a changelist. For Perforce and our Change Reports, a date works the same as a changelist.

What changes did arista make to C/projects?

What did he change recently?

item.p: Visit Change Reports.
Perforce provides many ways for refering to file revisions. To view the options for specifing files, changelists, dates, etc.

File Syntax
item.p: Changes may be made to a file indirectly via a integration (aka merge). Unfortunately, The 'p4 changes' and 'p4 filelog' commands reports these changes with the '-i' option. Unfortunately, they do not work for revision ranges [Perforce reports the entire integration history]. To circumvent this limitation

ul.li: Generate a list of all changes upto points A and B, and then take the difference (in Unix, 'diff'). See Perforce's Tech Note 27 for details.
Run 'p4 changes' on each integrated codeline. Since all changes are typically integrated, the combined list will give the desired information.
Note: Perforce does not distinguish between changes that are merged into a codeline and changes that are skipped via "accept yours".

item.p: In the GUI, use drag-and-drop to list the changes to a directory (Drag the directory to the changelist window).
Use the command line for detailed change information.

ul.li:
To list all files that changed from 2005/10/1 up to now (includes integrations):

item.title: What files were mistakenly deleted?
item.p: During a sync merge, the 'p4 integ -d' command may delete files that should not be deleted. To list the candidates,

ol.li:
List the files deleted by a sync or merge request.
p4 files ... | grep " delete " | sed 's/#.*//' | p4 -x - changes | egrep -i '(refresh|sync|merge)' | sort -u > sync.txt

section.title: Errors

item.title: '... - must refer to client '...'
item.p: The filename was misspelled in a 'p4 print' command. [Perforce was notified about this cryptic error message].

item.title: 'can't branch from ... Please use the 'Permit delete/re-adds' option.'

section.item:
The 'p4 integ' commands reports an error if a branch or merge may produce unexpected results. To override this error, add the integ -d flag. From the help documentation for p4 integ, By default, a non-existent toFile is only opened for branch or add if fromFile conforms to the condition that its revRange starts with a branch or add. (When revRange is not given, this condition is always met, because the implied revRange is #1 to #head.) The -d flag allows a non-existent toFile to be opened for branch or add even if the first revision of fromFile in revRange is an edit or an integrate.
An existing toFile is only opened for delete if it conforms to the condition that all of its revisions are already accounted for in previous integrations to or from fromFile. In other words, toFile is only opened for delete if all of its changes either came from fromFile or have been merged into fromFile. The -d flag allows an existing toFile to be opened for delete even if it doesn't conform to these conditions.

item.title: 'Client 'xyz' has files opened; use -f to force delete.'
item.p: You can not delete a client that has opened files. Unless you have superuser permission, you can not use '-f' to override.
Use 'p4 opened //...' to view the opened files
Use 'p4 revert -s //...' to revert unchanged files.
Use 'p4 revert //...' to throw away changes to the opened files.

item.title: 'Client map too twisted for directory list'
item.p: From Michael Shields of Perforce:

section.item:
When P4win starts the first time, it does not have a client. Go to ClientSpec::New to create a client.
You may view the depot without a client. Go to Settings::Options... and change P4Port to 'perforce:1666'. Then go to View and set 'Entire depot'.

item.title: 'file(s) not in client view'
item.p:
The requested file does not exist in your clientview.
Check Perforce's client mapping for the current directory
p4 where
Check Perforce's current directory (do they match your client?)
p4 info
Is your current directory a symlink? If so, consider using the '-d' option. See Perforce's Tech Note 44.

item.title: 'no permission for operation on file(s)'
item.p: You do not have "read" or "write" access to this file.

item.title: 'no permission to lock file'
item.p: You have 'open' access to the file but you do not have 'write' access. This can occur when we lock down the mainline for checkins, but allow checkouts for ongoing development.

item.title: 'no target file(s) in both client and branch view'
item.p: Perforce could not find any files. There may be a misspelling or missing directory name.
This message is misleading for "Integrate ... Using filespec ...". In this case, there are neither client nor branch views.
To help avoid this error, browse for the file or directory in P4Win, select it, and use ^C to copy the full pathname.

item.title: 'password not set'
item.p: Perforce did not find P4PASSWD in the NT registry, NT/Unix environment, or p4config.txt.
On the NT, be sure to check "remember password" whenever Perforce asks for the password. Otherwise it is not available to the command line or to SCC.DLL (e.g., Visual C++).
If your old userid was renamed, use the following procedure to reestablish access p4win:

ol.li: Set P4USER in your system environment (see the System control panel)

Launch p4win. If p4win reports an error, explicitly set your password using a command window (cmd)
p4 set P4PASSWD=xyz
Select User :: Set password, and change your password.

item.title: 'Path 'f:\xyz' is not under client's root 'f:\p4\all'
item.p: Every Perforce client has a root directory in your file system.
Perforce reports "not under client's root" when a prefix of the specified path is not the root directory. In this case, 'f:\xyz' is not the same as 'f:\p4\all'.
On the command line, you should use P4CONFIG and p4config.txt to assign the client to its root directory.

On NT, cygwin conventions can trip up Perforce. Check that forward and backward slashes match up. You should set the root of your Perforce clients using NT's back slashes. Then define a p4 alias to convert from cygwin to back slashes. See Configuring the tcsh Shell.

item.title: 'protected namespace - access denied'
item.p: You do not have access permission to this file. For example, if you try to add a file into "//product/DAS/xyz/...", you will get an error since the codeline is not specified (e.g., //product/DAS/main/...). The problem use often due to a typo or misspelling.

ol.li: Use 'p4 where ...' to check the mapping from client to depot and back.
Check the left-hand-side of your client spec. It needs to match an existing depot and codeline (e.g., '//product/DAS/main/...').
Check the wildcards of your client spec. They must match on both sides.
Check that the wildcards are preceeded by a slash (e.g., 'main/...' instead of 'main...').
See Write Permissions for the current protection rules.

item.p: [Copied from How to add files] If Perforce reports a write protect error,

ul.li: Check that your file maps to //express/MyProj/main/Readme.txt.
Check that you have write permission to //express.
The depot name must already exist.
The third directory must be either "main" or another codeline.

section.item:
"Request too large" means that the Perforce server scanned too many file revisions. The default limit is 80,000 file revisions. For example, if you tried to sync all files with 'p4 sync //...', you would get "Request too large". This helps prevent one user from hogging the server.
To view recent changes use client syntax and a revision range:
In the 2002.2 GUI, go to "Filter Submited Changelists.." and enter your client name and a revision range, e.g,
//barber-aurail-copper/...@262300,#head"
From your client root, enter the following command
p4 changes -m 20 ...@262300,#head
Other suggestions:
Limit your request to a directory and its subdirectories.
Review your client. If it contains wildcards ('*' or '...') instead of codelines, always limit your request to a directory.
Define or use a client for a codeline (e.g., 0-rev600 for version/6.0.0)
For 'p4 changes', limit your request to a user. You can drag and drop from the user pane to the changelist pane. The command line is ('p4 changes -u xyz ...').
Limit your request to a revision range (e.g., ...@234577,#head)
Review the Perforce documentation
p4 help maxresults

item.title: 'sh: /tmp/tmp.20311.0: cannot execute'
item.p: Check the following possible causes [mshields@perforce]

ul.li:
Permissions for /tmp should be:
drwxrwxrwt 6 root sys 440 Jul 29 17:05 tmp

sh needs to find P4EDITOR. Try using its absolute path.
setenv P4EDITOR /usr/bin/vi
Is there anything in your .profile that is causing an error when sh is forked?

item.title: 'Submit failed -- already locked by ...'
item.p: The file was opened for edit by another user and locked. The error message includes a clientspec. Call the user who owns the clientspec and ask them to submit or unlock the file.

item.title: 'You do not have permission for this operation'
item.p: Either your user name is misspelled, you do not belong to a Perforce group, or you do not have a license. Your Perforce userid should be the same as your regular userid.
Use 'p4 info' or p4win>Help>ShowConnectionInfo to identify your Perforce userid.
Use 'p4 users' or p4win>User>ViewUsers to verify that your userid matches your userid in Perforce.
See Perforce Write Protections for the currently defined groups, their members, and their write permissions. All groups have read access to the Perforce depots.
From the command line, type 'p4 groups YOUR_USERID'. It should list one or more groups.

item.title: Client 'xyz' can only be used from host 'Agamemnon'
item.p: The hostname assigned to the client does not match your hostname. Since a Perforce client corresponds to a workspace on a machine, it should not be used on another machine.
The hostname is case sensitive (i.e., 'agamemnon' is a different host than 'Agamemnon').
To override this error, use the -H global option [craig], e.g.,
To rename the client's host [e.g., you've renamed your machine]:

ol.li: Determine your hostname by selecting p4win>Help>Show Connection Info or by executing p4 info.
Modify the hostname assigned to the client by selecting p4win>ClientSpec>Edit xyz... or by executing p4 client. In p4win, you may need to right click on the client and Switch to xyz.

In p4win, Perforce will report a warning. If you are sure that the directory structure has not changed, ignore the warning. Otherwise, resync your workspace with Redo sync to the same revision or p4 sync -f.

item.title: Case sensitivity problems
item.p: Like CVS, Perforce is case-sensitive while Windows NT ignores case. This can cause troubles if someone checks in two files that differ only in case. One file will overwrite the other file for NT users. See Perforce Technote 003, Case sensitivity problems

item.title: CRLF vs. LF
item.p: Unix uses LF (\012) to terminate lines while Windows uses CRLF (\013\012) and Macintosh uses CR (\013).

Both Perforce and CVS servers store their text files as Unix files. [Perforce can be a Windows server instead]. On the Perforce and CVS servers, text files use LF line terminators. On the clients, text files use the local conventions (e.g., CRLF under Windows). This can cause confusion.

If a file with CRLF or CR line terminators gets checked in as a Unix file, the CR characters are stored on the server. When these files are checked out, the extra CR characters are retained. Under Unix, lines will end with CRLF instead of LF. Under Windows, lines will end with CRCRLF instead of CRLF. Editors are inconsistent about what happens. For example, WordPad treats CRCRLF as a unknown character.
To avoid CRLF problems under Windows or Macintosh:

ul.li: Use option 'shared' or 'local' in Perforce clients (2001.1). Option 'local' is the default. It is the same as 'crlf' in rev 2000.2. If you use 'shared', you can edit text files with any convention.
For 2000.2 clients (you should upgrade!), use option 'crlf' in Perforce clients. This is the default. Only use 'nocrlf' for special circumstances.
If you edit on windows and check in on Unix, be sure that your FTP program converts CRLF or CR to LF.
If you edit a file on a shared Unix disk, be sure that your editor is set for Unix conventions.

item.p: If an error occurs, it can be difficult to tell what is wrong. Use a binary editor or octal dump (e.g., 'od -c' on Unix).
Be sure to resync your files after a CRLF problem is fixed. Otherwise, any change that you make will conflict with the entire file.
See Perforce's Tech Note 63 for further discussion.

item.title: File ownership
item.p: Question: I am logged in on a Win2K box as fkim, domain NA. Under cygwin when I do UNIX like commands like touch, the resulting files have the ownership of fkim:None. But when I something in DOS or check something out using Perforce the resulting files have the ownership of Administrator:None.

The problem with this mixed up scheme is sometimes some UNIX commands tell me I don't have permission to modify a file. Does anyone know how to fix this? Should I just remove my fkim entry from /etc/passwd and let Windows think I'm Administrator?

Answer: You can also use ls -ln to see what numeric ID is being used on the files. I noticed the other day that the ID number for my account changed from 12399 to 11188 and all my perforce stuff was out of whack until I fixed my /etc/passwd to use the new number (with mkpasswd -u awaltman -d NA >> /etc/passwd) and chown -R'ed all of it to use the new ID number. I have no idea why the SID changed - possibly it is related to our switch to the NA domain? I think the SID was the same on both domains for a while there, but now they are different.

Also, you may want to check your CYGWIN environment variable for the ntsec/nontsec setting. I got all kinds of strangeness with a recent upgrade (1.3.12-4 -> 1.3.13-2) of the cygwin1.dll until I found that they changed the default to use ntsec. I added to my system environment a CYGWIN variable set to nontsec and that made things go back to they way they were. [awaltman]

item.p: If you submitted a change with an incorrect description, please send a request to road with the changelist number and the corrected description. Someone with superuser permission will correct your description.

ol.li: p4 groups userid - what groups to you belong to?
p4 groups dev - what groups does group 'dev' belong to?

p4 print //road/Perforce/main/protections/p4_protect.txt | egrep ' (dev|dev-edit|devtools|se-patch-55) '
See Write Permissions for the list.
Remember the single quotes with a space before and after.
write group dev-edit * //qa/web/version/... write group dev-edit * //road/web/main/... write group dev-edit * //road/Bugzilla/main/bugzilla/bug_status.html write group dev-edit * //road/Bugzilla/main/bugzilla/bugfaq.html write group dev-edit * //se/web/main/... write group dev-edit * //se/web/version/... write group dev-edit * //se/web/dev/... write group devtools * //road/Perforce/main/... write group devtools * //road/devtools/dev/... write group devtools * //road/devtools/main/... write group devtools * //road/devtools/version/... write group dev * //dev/*/dev/... write group dev * //dev/*/main/... write group dev * //dev/*/version/... write group dev * -//dev/DAF/... write group dev * //*/*/dev/tremont/... write group dev * //product/*/main/... write group dev * //qa/ctstest/main/... write group dev * //qa/ctstest/dev/... write group dev * //qa/ctstest/version/... read group everyone * //*/*/dev/... read group everyone * //*/*/final/... read group everyone * //*/*/main/... read group everyone * //*/*/version/... list group everyone * //*/* read group everyone * //user/...

Read the list from bottom to top and find the last line that references your depot. If there is a leading "-", you do not have rights to that depot. Otherwise you have the listed right.
For example, the 'dev' group has write access to '//*/*/dev/tremont/...', has read-only access to '-//dev/DAF/...', and has no access to '//*/*/xyz/...'.

item.title: P4 Changes/Fixes (p4 describe) does not include files or diffs
item.p: If a user does not have list permission, 'p4 describe' does show the list of the files for a change list. In the Bugzilla/Perforce integration, Bugzilla uses the 'perforce' userid.

Use 'p4 groups user_id' to determine the groups that a user belongs to. Every user should belong to a group that is a member of the 'dev' group. If not, negative permissions in the protection table will turn off 'list' access.

item.title: Why is Perforce slow?
item.p: In May 2002, Road upgraded to 2002.1. This has improved response time. Perforce implemented MaxScanRows; it prevents run away requests. They also optimized the normal case of "aligned clients".
Some things you can do to speed things up:

ul.li: For wireless and remote clients, set option 'compress'. It is about twice as fast as 'nocompress'. It is about twice as slow for hardwired clients.
For remote clients, set the Server Port to 10.2.128.95:1666 instead of perforce:1666. VPN users report problems with DNS.
In p4win, turn off option 'Poll the server every 10 minutes'.

Avoid commands that look at many files. For example, deleting and resyncing a devtools client deletes and downloads 30,000 files.
The time taken by most Perforce commands depends on the the number of files involved. Perforce acquires read and write locks as needed. A write lock prevents read locks. Locks are acquired in request order. Read locks must close before a write lock can occur.
Check your network speed with 'tracert perforce'. On the internal LAN, the response time is <10ms.

Avoid 'p4 dirs //*'. Perforce contains a performance bug regarding remote depopts. The dirs command retrieves all files from the remote depot before generating the output. Unfortunately, the depot browser (p4db) issues a 'p4 dirs //*' command for every directory (reported to Perforce).

Avoid remote depots. Directly access harry-lime:1666 instead of adding a remote depot to perforce. Perforce's implementation may slow down commands such as "p4 dirs" [Re: slow command p4 dirs //* (CALL#335510)].
Read e-mail :-). Perforce is a shared medium. If someone tries to sync all files, it locks up the server for a while. There's still room for improvement.

item.p: Other causes for no response

ul.li: A Perforce checkpoint is taken every Sunday at 2AM. This prevents access for 20 minutes.
A Perforce 'obliterate' locks out users. This takes about 10 minutes per file spec. It is rarely done.
Road is making a new branch. This involves about 40,000 files. It will delay other users for about a minute.
IT is running a network backup. Sometimes a full backup occurs during the day. If so, perforce performance drops considerably.

item.p: MaxScanRows will report an error in the following cases:

ul.li: Do not create clientspecs with "//product/*/main/..." or a similar file spec. It is OK to use "//product/...". If so, you will always need "sync ...".

Do not create branchspecs with "//product/*/main/..." or a similar file spec. It may block all update access (p4 edit and p4 submit) to all of Perforce for all users for five to fifteen minues. Please explicitly list depot, project, and codeline in all branch specs.

Do not search all files with "p4 files //xyz/...abc...". If you misspell the depot name, Perforce searches every file. If you spell the name correctly, Perforce searches every codeline in the depot. Please limit searches to a codeline (e.g., //product/DAS/main/...).
Since Perforce indexes its databases by the filename and //product is the bulk of the files, a branchspec of "//product/..." will search over half of the database. It is not blocked by MAXRESULTS.

item.p: Perforce superusers can identify the cause of a Perforce block.

ul.li: Use top to find the blocking process.

Search its last command via
sudo tail -100000 /home/perforce/logs/p4d | grep " nnn "

Use Michael Shields log analyzer for more detailed information [public.perforce.com:1666://guest/michael_shields/src/p4loga/]
sudo tail -100000 /home/perforce/logs/p4d > log
/work/local/bin/p4loga

To look for all interesting events:
tail -100000 /home/perforce/logs/p4d >~/perforce-block.txt
cat perforce-block.txt | grep -v 'server info' | egrep -v 'user-(dirs|fstat|depots|opened|review|changes|client)' | more

item.p: Notes from Michael Shields of Perforce [2002/5/2 (CALL#317063)]
item.pre:
> >The way that syncing works is that the compute phase calculates what files > >need to be transferred; files such as db.have will be read-locked during the > >compute phase of the sync. Then locks are released, after which the transfer > >of files across the network begins. At a file-level granularity, the client > >notifies the server that it has recieved a file, which causes the server to > >take a quick write lock on db.have in order to update the client's have list > >to reflect the file received. > > Our users routinely sync 28,000 files. Does this cause 28,000 write > locks on db.have?
If the compute phase of the sync determines that of 28,000 files on a client's have list, five files need to updated, then five quick write locks will be taken against db.have after each of the five files have been transferred to the client. On the other hand, if the compute phase of the sync determines that all 28,000 files need to be updated, then 28,000 quick write locks will be taken against db.have after each of the 28,000 files have been transferred to the client. This is one of the reasons why p4 sync -f #have is not recommended as a standard practice.
> We average 95% cache hits. > > We average 300 MBytes of free physical memory. Is this too high? Should > we be using more memory for disk caching? The kernel is using > half of the pages, the free list has about 30% of the pages, other users > have about 20% of the pages. Each page represents 8K. We have > 1Gbyte total.
In general, you want to keep memory as utilized as possible, without swapping. In Solaris 2.8, I believe that cached disk pages live in what is accounted as free memory. There is also the concept of "freebehind" on Solaris that may affect how quickly disk pages are cached.
What "other users" are on this machine? In your environment, this machine should probably be dedicated to Perforce.
You may also want to consider adding memory to this machine. 1GB for a Solaris server is on the light side these days.
> We average 800 MBytes of available swap space.
Don't go there.
> >2. How large is your db.working table? > > 27 Megs.
This is larger than perhaps it needs to be. If you're not doing so already, perhaps you should start a campaign to reduce the number of open files. I know that I for one occasionally leaves a file open and forgets about it.
> We use client -d when we rebuild the product from scratch. That typically > happens at night when the system is lightly loaded.
And this is fine, as long as you realize the performance implications of the p4 client -d. Perish the thought that "last night's build failed, so we'll kick it off again now during prime time." If this happens more than it should, you may want to consider retooling this to eliminate the p4 client -d.

item.title: How does Perforce work?
item.p: Perforce consists of a server (p4d) and a thin client (p4, p4win, etc.).

There is a proprietary API to implement new clients. It is shipped as binary libraries. To see an execution log add the global option, '-vrpc=1' for commands and '-vrpc=5' for commands+data. There are other trace options but they require source to understand.
The server contains an optimized version of the Berkeley DB B++ database. It uses RCS for file revisions.

item.title: What came first, 'p4' or 'perforce'?
item.p: The precursor to Perforce was p3. When the company tried to register "p4" [or perhaps "p3"], the name was already taken. This lead to the choice of "perforce". [Wally Dutchess and Jeff Bowles].
On April 16, 2001, Marriam-Webster selected "perforce" as the word of the day [R. Blum]:
item.blockquote:
The Word of the Day for April 16 is:
perforce \per-FORSS\ (adverb) : by force of circumstances
example sentence:
Lorel and Mica's tiny vineyard produces a limited quantity of top-quality chardonnays that are perforce rather pricey.
Did you know?
Shakespeare had it both ways. English borrowed "par force" from Middle French in the 14th century. "Par" meant "by" (from Latin "per") and the French word "force" had the same meaning as its English equivalent, which was already in use by then. At first, "perforce" meant quite literally "by physical coercion" - a meaning still in use in Shakespeare's lifetime (1564-1616), though it's no longer used today. "He rush'd into my house and took perforce my ring away," wrote the Bard in _The Comedy of Errors_. But the weakened sense of "perforce" had also come into use by Shakespeare's day. In _Henry IV, Part 2_, we find ". . . your health; the which, if you give o'er to stormy passion, must perforce decay."

item.title: What is the difference between yours and theirs?
item.p: p4 resolve uses yours to refer to the destination of the resolve and theirs to refer to the source of the resolve. The source (theirs) is always files in the depot. The destination (yours) is always files in your workspace. It is an unfortunately choice of terminalogy and will cause confusion until you get used to it.
When you resolve changes, think of yourself as standing on the destination (yours) and pulling changes from the depot (theirs).
